T H E A T R E ROYAL,

COVEM-GARDEN.

Tliis present MONDAY, January 15, 1827,
W i l l b e acted, Slutkspeare's Tragedy of

-

KING JOHN.

ROMANTIC ROCKS, intermixed with CASCADES and W A T E R F A L L S ,
which, by the convulsion of the Elements, become agitated, and Overflowed by a

THE NEW PANTOMIME EVERY EVENING
Tomorrow, (16th time) the Opera of The SERAGLIO.
Ibrahim, Mr. WARDE, Belmonte, Mr.SAPIO, Constanza, Miss HUGHES, Bh>nda, Madame VESTRIS.
On Saturday, the Comedy of the MAN of the WORLD. Sir Pertinax Macsycophant, Mr. YOUNG.
On Monday, Mr. KEA'N will appear in KING RICHARD the THIRD.
On Tuesday, an OPERA.
On Wednesday, the Comedy of The CLANDESTINE MARRIAGE.

After a very protracted Indisposition, M I S S
C H E S T E R will resume b< r engagement on Tuesday
next, i n the Character of L A D Y T E A Z L E . — O n which night M R . C . K E M B L E will perform
the P a r t of C H A R L E S S U R F A C E .
__

_ . .

.

Mr.

K E A N

having determined to leave the Stage at the conclusion of the present Season, has entered into an
engagement at this Theatre for a limited number of nights.
On Monday, he will perform King Richard—and on Wednesday, Sir Giles Overreach.
^tomorrow, will be revived the Opera of NATIVE LAND. — The Music by Mr. BISHOP. ~~
The principal Characters by Mr WOOD, Mr. BLANCHARD, Mr. DIDDEAR, Mr. G. PENSON,
Miss HUG I Es, Madame V ESTRIS, Miss GOWARD, Miss CAWSE {their first appearance in this Opera.)
On Monday, Mr. KEAN will appear in KING RICHARD the THIRD.
On Tuesday, the Comedy of The SCHOOL for SCANDAL.
On Wednesday, theComedv of A N E W WAY to PAY OLD DEBTS. Sir Giles, Mr. KEAN.
On Thursday, an OPERA."

PART I.

O V E R T U R E t o OBERON
C. H . v o n W e b e r .
MOZART'S SECOND G R A N D M O T T E T T O ,

EXTRAORDINARY ASSEMBLAGE OF

Vocal and Instrumental Talent.
T H I S E V E N I N G , F R I D A Y , MARCH 2 8 , 1828,

& <&rano performance of

AND M O D E R N MUSIC

^

H.

R.

Accompanied on the Flute by

Mr. NICHOLSON.

B I S H O P ,

Who, in concluding the Season of these Performances, has the satisfaction to announce the following;
concentration of VOCAL and INSTRUMENTAL talent.

T H E Committee most respectfully inform the Subscribers and the Public in general, that finding the numerous
applications of Distressed Families for relief, far exceed the Annual Receipts, have determined upon taking a
Benefit in aid of their Funds, at the above Theatre. The Committee therefore, earnestly solicit the Friends of
Humanity to assist them in their undertaking; and support an Institution which has extended its benevolence to some Thousands of suffering Individuals, many of whom have been raised from the most abject
state of penury and want, by the timely assistance afforded them.
Boxes 7s. Second Price 3s. 6d.—Pit 3s.(id. Second Price 2s.—Gallery 2s. Srcond Price Is.—Upper Gallery Is.
TICKETS and PLACES to be had at ihe Box-Office ; and likewise of the following Members of the Institution, by whom
Places and Private Hoxes will be promptly secured :
Mr. P.assett, Dean-street,
Mr.Hitchman, 42, Seymour-place,
Mr. Cobden, Leicester-square,
Mr. Hunt, 27, St. James's-street,
Mr. Dunstone,52, Emest-street,Regent's-pirk Mr. Limbert, 61, Oxford-street,
Mr. Gibson, 11, Norton-street.
Mr. Newman, Greek-street,
Mr. Gooch, 43, Curzon-street, May-fair,
Mr. Palmer, 174, Oxford-street,
Mr. Hatt, 148, Holborn-bars,

| Mr. Rowland, S. Broad-street, Goldea-sqora,
Mr.Tuff-eil, 7, York-street, Middlesex-hospital
Mr Walton, 24. Wardonr-street,
I Mr. B. Welis 9, New CaT.ndish-strret,
\ Mr.Youatt, a, Nassau-street.Middlesex-hoipital

And of Mr. H. R. LONGMATE, SECRETARY, NO. 74, Berwick-stre*, Oxford-street.

I N the interval of vacation no industry or expence
has been spared to render this favoured place of
amusement worthy of the British Public. T h e whole
of the interior has been newly decorated, Chandeliers have been added to the second circle,and every
thins: that can contribute to the comfort as well as
the entertainment of the audience, has been carefully considered, and anxiously carried into effect.
T h e Dramatic Corps has been strengthened by
the addition of Provincial Performers of the greatest
celebrity.
Mr. G R I E V E , Mr. G R I E V E , J u n . and M r .
W . G R I E V E , have been engaged on a variety
of new and splendid S T O C K S C E N E R Y ; and

A MAGNIFICENT
N E W ACT DROP-CUBTAIN
has been designed and executed by
Mr. R O B E R T S :
T h e intent of which is to harmonize with the general
effect of the decorations. T h e design—A Temple,
supposed to be erected in the Metropolis, in honour of

SHAKSPEARE.
Mr. F A W C E T T , Stage

Manager.

In order to keep the Lower Circle of Boxes perfectly select, no
places will be kept but such as are paid for at the time of taking.
BOXES, 7-

PIT, 3s. 6<L

GALLERY 2«.

UPPER GALLERY Is.

Second Price will be admitted at the end of the third act of Plays, and at the
end of the second act of Operas. The Time will vary from a Quarter before
Nine o'clock, till a Quarter after.

Theatre Royal, Covent-Garden.
November 23, 1828.

T h e Melancholy S t a t e of Destitution in which t h e

WIDOWS
CHILDREN
a r e left, of poor

Douglas&Fennell
(l.heMen

who lost their JAves at Covent Garden
Theatre,)

Induces Mr. FAWCETT most respectfully to implore the
assistance of the Public to enable him to alleviate their
Sufferings. They have each THREE YOUNG CHILDREN, and are both l i k e l y to become Mothers of a
posthumous Offspring.
To the private Friends and Acquaintance of Mr.
Fawcett, he begs to s a y , t h a t no personal civility will
be half so acceptable to him a s the smallest Contributions to these afflicted Persons.

SUBSCRIPTIONS
will be received b y Mr. F a w c e t t ; or a t the Box-Office
of the Theatre, b y Mr. Notter.
Printed by W. Reynold*, 9, Donmark*cem\ Strand.

The Re-Opening of
Covent-Garden T h e a t r e .
The Public attention is respoctf a l l y solicited to the
following Facts:—
The Gasometers, and Apparatus for making Gas, are
destroyed, and no more Gas will be manufactured within
the walls of the Theatre.
The Circles of Boxes will be illuminated with 'Wax.
The Lights in the front of the Stage, and of every
internal avenue to Box, Pit- and Galleries, will be produced by the agency of the purest Oil.
The Proprietors and Managers, having called in the powers of Chemistry,
haying exerted the most indefatigable industry, and having cheerfully expended
a considerable sum in rendering Covent-Garden Theatre worthy the Patronage
it has hitherto been favoured with, the Public are respectfully invited to the

REOPENING
On THURSDAY N E X T , Nov. 27, 1828,
WHEN

Mr. R E A N
will perform, for the fourth time this season, the character of

To which will be adder! T h e

in that

character)

R E - O&EMMMG
OP

Covent-Garden Theatre.
THURSDAY, DECEMBER 4, 182&

The Public attention is respectfally solicited to the
following important Documents:—

(Copy.)
LORD CHAMBERLAIN'S OFFICE,
November 29, 1828.
GENTLEMEN,

I am commanded by the Lord Chamberlain to
acquaint you, that his Grace considers it necessary that a satisfactory Report
should be transmitted to him as to the safety of the Theatre Royal, CoventOnrden, for the reception of the Public, before the House Re-Opeus.
x
1 am, Gentlemen,
.
Your obedient Servant.
T. B. MASH.
The Proprietors of the Theatre Royal, Covent-Garden^
In consequence of this Command, the following1 Certificates were submitted
to his Grace, who was pleased to sanction the Re-opening of the Theatre by
his Authority,

Certificates*
HAYING been employed by the Proprietors of the
Theatre Royal, Covent-Garden, to superintend the'removal of the Gas, and
iu the repairs of the damage occasioned by the accident, I HEREBY CERTIFY, that the Gasometers are destroyed, and every means for the manufacture of Gas entirely removed, so as to render the Theatre perfectly secure;
—and I AM OF OPINION that the Theatre may open with perfect safety.
Dec. 3, 18-28.

SAMUEL BEAZLEY,

Architect.

Theatre Royal, Covent-Garden, Dec. 1, 1828.
WE, the undersigned, having been called in by the Proprietors
of the above Theatre, to destroy the apparatus formerly used for manufacturing Oil Gas on the Premises, H E R E B Y CERTIFY, that the whole of
the apparatus which can in the smallest degree endanger the Theatre, has
been entirely destroyed, so that no inconvenience whatever can arise to the
future operations of the Theatre,
JOHN EVANS,
Superintendant of the Chartered Gas Light and Coke
Company's Works, Horseferry Road,
THOMAS EDGE,
Manufacturer of Gas Light Apparatus,
Gnat Peter-street, Westminster.
Printed by W. Reynolds,^, Denmark-court, Strand.

Covent-Garden Theatre.

Closed for One Week
ADDRESS.
W H E N the brilliancy of GAS illumination attracted
Public admiration, the Proprietors of this Theatre
anxious to adopt eveiy Improvement which would
give brilliancy to the Scenery, and the appearance of the
Theatre, introduced it; and to prevent the accidents which
the best Street illumination is liable to, they a t a great
expense constructed Gasometers : finding however t h a t
with the utmost care and skill, the introduction of Gas in
the audience part of the Theatre, produced an offensive
odour, and the Public having suffered inconvenience and
disappointment in their amusements, b y the mischievous
agency of some malignant and interested Persons; the
Proprietors have determined to remove the Gas, not only
from the Box Circles, but from a l l internal avenues leading to them, a s well a s to the P i t and Galleries.
But a s this important Alteration cannot be effectually
done, while the Theatre is nightly open, without the
Public being put to inconvenience, the Managers have
determined to submit to the heavy loss of Closing their
Theatre, rather than allow the Public to suffer any drawback to their Theatrical Enjoyments.
The Public is in consequence respectfully informed, t h a t
a s the proposed Improvements cannot be executed in
less than a Week, the Theatre w i l l remain

CLOSE!} TILL MONDAY,
THE 24th

INSTANT;

when they hope to welcome t h e Public to a Theatre,
where no Expense will be spared, or Zeal remitted, to
render i t worthy the liberal Patronage it h a s ever
enjoyed.

J. FAWCETT, Stage Manager
Printwl by If. RrrS,otr>$, s), l>erinrirk-«ourt,Strand.

*

m,E~o&mwrxma
Oe

Covent-Grarden Theatre*
EVERY
OBSTACLE
to Re-Opening this Theatre
being now REMOVED,
by Certificates of scientific and
practical B£en as to the Safety as well as the Purification
of the Theatre, It is most respectfully announced that

Tomorrow,

Thursday,

Dee* 4-,

Performance will t a k e place*
The Public attention is respectfully solicited to fho
following Facts:—
The Gasometers, and Apparatus for making Gas, are
destroyed, and no more Gas will he manufactured within
the walls of the Theatre.
The Circles of Boxes will be illuminated with W a s .
The Lights in the front of the Stage, and of every
internal avenue to Box, Fit, and Galleries, w i l l be the
purest Oil.
TOMORROW, THURSDAY Dec 4, 1828, will be acted the Comedy of The

Covent-Garden Theatre.
EVERY
OBSTACLE
to Re-Opening this Theatre
being now REMOVED,
b y Certificates of scientific and
practical Men as to the Safety as well as the PorificatioB
of the Theatre, It is most respectfully announced that on

THURSDAY NEXT, Dec. 4 ,
Performance will t a k e place
The Public attention is respectfully solicited to the
following Facts:—
The Gasometers, and Apparatus for making Gas, are
destroyed, and no more Gas will be manufactured withto
the walls of the Theatre.
The Circles of Boxes will be illuminated with W a x .
The Lights in the front of the Stage, and of every
internal avenue to Box, Fit, and Galleries, will be the
purest Oil.

Thii FUND was fint instituted the 23d December, 17R5. and confirmed by Act of Parliament, (1*33,) fer tie
purpose of supporting INDIGENT and INFIRM ACTORS and ACTRESSES,
and relieving their WIDOWS and CHILDREN.
Trustees— Sir Coutts T r o t t e r , Bart.—John Fawcett, e s q — H e n r y H a r r i s , esq.
Stewards—Messrs.
B a k e r — B e l l a m y — B . P . Bellamy—Blanchard—Broadhurst—Claremont—Duruset—
Egerton—Evans—Farley—Fawcett—Horrebow—Jones—Keeley—Listen—Mathews—Mac ready—
Meadows—Rayner—Raymond—Sinclair—Taylor—Yates—Young.
T r e o i u r e r , M r . Fawcett—Secretary, Mr, E g e r t o n .
The Musical Department will be ander the Direction of SIR GEOBGE SMART.
T I C K E T S One Guinea each ( W i n e included,)
to be had of the Stewards, at the Fund Office, Stage
Door,
Hart-Street,
Covent-Garden,
from 12 till 4 daily;
and at the Freemasons'
Tavern.
O " The Hall Doors will be opened at Five o'clock, and the Dinner on Table at Six, (immediately on the arrival of
Their Roval Highnesses.)
T h e Stewards have the gratification to announce that they shall have the honour of presenting to the View
of their illustrious, noble, and distinguished Guests, the celebrated C U P , carved from S H A K S P E A R E ' S
Mulberry T r e e , and given b y the Corporation of Stratford
to G A R R I C K , whose favorite Song of
"Behold
this/air
Goblet, 'twas carv'd from the Tree," will be s u n g by Mr. B R A H A M , who has kindly volunteered
his powerful aid on t h e occasion—and Miss H U G H E S has also consented to sing from the Ladies' Gallery.

This FUND was first instituted the 53d December, 1765, and confirmed by Act of Parliament, (1(76,) for the
purpose of supporting INDIGENT and INFIRM ACTORS and ACTRESSES,
and relieving their WIDOWS and CHILDREN.
Trustees-- Sir Coutts Trotter, Bart.—John Fawcett, esq —Henry H a r r i s , esq.
Stewards—Mess.
Baker—Bellamy—B. P . Bellamy—Blanchard—Broadhurst—Duruset—Egerton—Evans—
Farley—Fawcett—Horrebow—Jones—Keeley—Liston—Mathews- Macready—Meadows—Mears— Power—
Rayner—Raymond—J. Reeve—Sinclair—Taylor—Yates—Young.
Treasurer,
M r . Fawcett—Secretary, Mr. Egerton.
,
The Musical Department will he under the Direction of SIR GEORGE SMART.
'Les Trois Troubadours,
and the Bohemian Brothers,
have kindly tendered the aid of their powerful abilities
on the occasion.—JMhs Hughes will also sing from the Ladies' Gallery
T I C K E T S One Guinea each, (Wine included,)
to be had of the Stewards, at the Fund Office. Stage
Door,
Hart Street, Covent Garden, from 12 till 4 daily ; at Sams's Royal Library,
St. James's Street;
and at
'the Freenuisons'
'lavern.
fcj- The Hall Doors will be opened at Five o'clock.
